sentences.text: The ''Miami Herald'' reported that in a 19 August interview with ''Últimas Noticias'', when Tarek William Saab|Tarek Saab, Venezuela's attorney general, was asked if Machado would be charged with homicide, he responded: "At any moment, any of them could be charged and held responsible as the intellectual authors of all these events". Saab, who is under Venezuelan sanctions|sanctions for multiple alleged offenses, is charged by human rights organizations as "being one of the key people in the regime's efforts to use the Venezuelan justice system as an instrument of political persecution".

references.text: <ref name=MHCouldCharge>{{cite news|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/venezuela/article291191975.html|work=MiamiHerald|title=Venezuela could charge opposition leader Machado with murder, regime's prosecutor says|first=Antonio Maria |last=Delgado |date=19 August 2024|access-date=19 August 2024}} Also available at [https://gazette.com/ap/international/venezuela-could-charge-opposition-leader-machado-with-murder-regime-s-prosecutor-says/article_88d4dff3-eb30-5b8f-bca4-a51a69abb0ee.html Colorado Springs Gazette]</ref>

<ref name=ECWillBeCharged>{{cite news|url=https://efectococuyo.com/politica/saab-advierte-que-machado-sera-imputada-en-cualquier-momento/|work=Efecto Cocuyo|date=19 August 2024|access-date=19 August 2024|language=es|title=Saab advierte que Machado será imputada 'en cualquier momento'|trans-title=Saab warns that Machado will be charged 'at any time}} Referring to the [https://www.elnacional.com/venezuela/tarek-william-saab-en-cualquier-momento-maria-corina-machado-pudiera-ser-imputada/ interview published] by ''El Nacional (Venezuela)|El Nacional''.</ref>

<ref name=MHCouldCharge/> Saab held Machado and González responsible for what he said were a series of events directed from the United States.<ref name=MHCouldCharge/> A few days before Saab's statement, the Colombian Peace & Reconciliation Foundation (Pares) had released its third report on election violence in Venezuela, stating that most of the victims during the election were "members of the main opposition parties", and that over 91% of the violent acts were committed by Venezuelan security forces.<ref name=MHCouldCharge/><ref name=Pares3>{{cite report|url=https://www.pares.com.co/post/desapariciones-deportaciones-y-detenciones-arbitrarias-los-resultados-del-tercer-informe-de-violen|title= Desapariciones, deportaciones y detenciones arbitrarias: Los resultados del Tercer Informe de Violencia Político-Electoral en Venezuela|language=es|trans-title=Disappearances, deportations and arbitrary detentions: The results of the Third Report on Political-Electoral Violence in Venezuela|publisher=Pares: Fundación Paz y Reconciliación|location=Bogota, Colombia|date=16 August 2024|access-date=20 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name=ElDiarioParesFoundation>{{cite news|url=https://eldiario.com/2024/08/14/fundacion-pares-responsabilizo-autoridades-venezuela-violencia-elecciones/|work=El Diario de Caracas|title=Fundación Pares responsabilizó a las autoridades de Venezuela por la violencia durante las elecciones|language=es|trans-title=Pares Foundation blamed Venezuelan authorities for violence during elections|first=Jose|last=Villa|date=14 August 2024|access-date=19 August 2024}}</ref>

content.title: González summons, arrest warrant and exile

sentences.text:
, then 74, in 2024]]
Following the TSJ ruling on 22 August, attorney general Saab told journalists that González would be called to testify in a criminal investigation of alleged electoral fraud. González was summoned to appear on 26 August on the charge of usurping the function of the CNE by uploading election records to ''www.resultsconvzla.com''. He was also accused of forgery, instigating disobedience, conspiracy and association to commit a crime, and computer crimes. Attorney {{ill|Joel García|es|Joel García (abogado)}} said the summons was unclear on whether González was accused or called as a witness or an expert. He also ignored the second summons.

references.text: <ref name=InfoBaeFraud>{{cite news|url=https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/08/23/fraude-en-venezuela-la-fiscalia-chavista-citara-a-gonzalez-urrutia-por-una-investigacion-penal/|work=Infobae|date=23 August 2024|access-date=23 August 2024|title=Fraude en Venezuela: la Fiscalía chavista citó a declarar a González Urrutia por una investigación penal|language=es|trans-title=Fraud in Venezuela: the Chavista Prosecutor's Office summoned González Urrutia to testify for a criminal investigation}}</ref>

<ref name=ReutersToBeCalled>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/venezuela-opposition-leader-gonzalez-be-called-testify-about-opposition-website-2024-08-23/|work=Reuters|title=Venezuela opposition leader Gonzalez to be called to testify about vote tally website, AG says|author1= Buitrago, Deisy|author2=Sequera, Vivian|date=23 August 2024|access-date=23 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name=NTN24FormallySummons>{{cite news|url=https://www.ntn24.com/noticias-judicial/fiscalia-venezolana-cita-formalmente-al-excandidato-edmundo-gonzalez-y-lo-acusa-de-graves-delitos-509601|work=NTN24|date=24 August 2024|access-date=24 August 2024|language=es|title=Fiscalía venezolana cita formalmente al excandidato Edmundo González y lo acusa de graves delitos|trans-title=Venezuelan Prosecutor's Office formally summons former candidate Edmundo González and accuses him of serious crimes}}</ref>

<ref name=NTN24FormallySummons/><ref name=ProsecutorSummoned>{{cite news|url= https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/08/24/fraude-en-venezuela-la-fiscalia-chavista-cito-a-declarar-a-edmundo-gonzalez-urrutia-el-proximo-lunes-26-de-agosto-por-una-investigacion-penal/ |work=Infobae|date=24 August 2024|access-date=24 August 2024|language=es|title=Fraude en Venezuela: la Fiscalía chavista citó a declarar a Edmundo González Urrutia el próximo lunes 26 de agosto por una investigación penal|trans-title=Fraud in Venezuela: The Chavista Prosecutor's Office summoned Edmundo González Urrutia to testify next Monday, August 26, for a criminal investigation}}</ref>

<ref name=AFPCandidateDue/> A second summons for the following day was issued when González, as anticipated, did not appear; if an individual fails to comply with a summons three times, an arrest warrant can be issued.<ref name=ChangeinLife>{{cite news|url=https://english.elpais.com/international/2024-08-26/the-change-in-the-life-of-edmundo-gonzalez-from-unknown-diplomat-to-vortex-of-the-venezuelan-crisis.html|work=El País|access-date=26 August 2024|title=The change in the life of Edmundo González: From unknown diplomat to vortex of the Venezuelan crisis|date=26 August 2024|author=Moleiro, Alonso}}</ref>

<ref name=ReutersSecondSummons>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/venezuelan-attorney-generals-office-issues-second-summons-opposition-leader-2024-08-26/|work=Reuters|access-date=26 August 2024|title=Venezuelan attorney general's office issues second summons for opposition leader Gonzalez|date=26 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name=AFPSecondSummons>{{cite news|url=https://www.barrons.com/news/venezuela-opposition-candidate-ignores-second-summons-c6cc5d29|work=Barron's|publisher=Agence France-Press|date=27 August 2024|access-date=27 August 2024|title=Venezuela Opposition Candidate Ignores Second Summons|author=Tovar, Javier}}</ref>

sentences.text: After ignoring a third summons, an arrest warrant was issued on 2 September for González for crimes including criminal association and conspiracy after prosecutor Luis Ernesto Dueñez Reyes "requested Gonzalez be arrested for usurpation of functions, falsification of public documents, instigation to disobey the law, conspiracy and association", according to Reuters. José Vicente Haro, González's attorney, said that the attorney general's office would not receive affidavits needed for González's defense and "explaining why González ignored three summons".

references.text: <ref name=APArrestWarrant>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/venezuela-attorney-general-requests-arrest-warrant-opposition-leader-gonzalez-2024-09-02/|work=Reuters|date=2 September 2024|access-date=3 September 2024|title=Venezuela issues arrest warrant for opposition leader Gonzalez, AG says|author1=Sequera, Vivian|author2=Armas, Mayela}}</ref>

<ref name=GuardianArrestWarrant>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/sep/03/edmundo-gonzalez-venezuela-election-opposition-leader-prosecutors-arrest-warrant|work=The Guardian|date=2 September 2024|access-date=3 September 2024|title=Venezuela judge issues arrest warrant for opposition leader after disputed election|author= Phillips, Tom}}</ref>

<ref name=ReutersLawyerSays>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/lawyer-venezuela-opposition-leader-gonzalez-says-ag-would-not-receive-writ-2024-09-04|work=Reuters|date=4 September 2024|access-date=4 September 2024|title=Venezuela opposition leader's lawyer says attempt to file defense document refused}}</ref>

sentences.text: After the election, González sought refuge secretly in the Dutch Embassy through 5 September, after which he spent several days in the Spanish embassy in Caracas, and was granted asylum, leaving on a Spanish Armed Forces flight on 7 September 2024. His wife accompanied him on the flight to Madrid, where they would join a daughter who lives there.

references.text: <ref name=APFleesVenezuela>{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/venezuela-opposition-candidate-gonzalez-asylum-spain-749131a560dd9d762e04e201e43b9495|publisher= Associated Press|date= 8 September 2024|access-date= 8 September 2024|title=Opposition presidential candidate González flees Venezuela for asylum in Spain|author1=Rueda, Jorge|author2=Goodman, Joshua|author3=Wilson, Joseph}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=8 September 2024|title=In diepste geheim bood Nederland onderdak aan oppositieleider Venezuela |url=https://www.rtl.nl/nieuws/politiek/artikel/5469697/diepste-geheim-nederland-ambassade-onderdak-oppositieleider |access-date=8 September 2024 |work=RTL Nederland|language=nl|trans-title=The Netherlands secretly offered shelter to Venezuelan opposition leader}}</ref>

<ref name=ElDiarioAsylum>{{cite news|url=https://eldiario.com/2024/09/07/edmundo-gonzalez-abandono-venezuela-asilo-espana/|work=El Diario de Caracas|date= 7 September 2024|access-date=8 September 2024|language=es|title=Edmundo González abandonó Venezuela tras solicitar asilo político en España|trans-title=Edmundo González left Venezuela after requesting political asylum in Spain}}</ref>

<ref name=ElMundoNegotiatingExile>{{cite news |url= https://www.elmundo.es/internacional/2024/09/08/66dd0f9afc6c83894b8b4580.html|work=El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo|language=es|date=8 September 2024|access-date=8 September 2024|title=Edmundo González vuela a Madrid tras negociar su exilio|trans-title=Edmundo González flies to Madrid after negotiating his exile|author1= Lozano, Daniel|author2= Piña, Raúl}}</ref>

sentences.text: Machado stated that Maduro's administration had "lost all sense of reality”, and that the threat of arrest would further unite the opposition. Haro, González's attorney, said that González is not planning to seek asylum.<ref name=BrazilCondemn/>

references.text: <ref name=GuardianArrestWarrant/> PUD (the main opposition platform) strongly condemned the escalating political persecution aimed at González, stating that a "regime" that was unable to publish "a single ''acta'' that supported the fraudulent [election] result announced by the CNE" was able to quickly issue an arrest warrant for the winner of those elections.<ref name=OppositionCondemn>{{cite news|url=https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/09/03/la-oposicion-de-venezuela-condeno-la-orden-de-detencion-del-regimen-de-maduro-en-contra-de-edmundo-gonzalez/|work=Infobae|access-date=3 September 2024|date=2 September 2024|language=es|title=La oposición de Venezuela condenó la orden de detención del régimen de Maduro en contra de Edmundo González|trans-title=Venezuela's opposition condemned the Maduro regime's arrest warrant against Edmundo González}}</ref>

sentences.text: On his weekly program, Maduro did not directly address the arrest warrant, but dedicated a portion of the show to González, calling him a "coward", saying that "no one is above the law", claiming González and Machado were responsible for the 2024 Venezuelan blackouts, and announcing a decree for an early Christmas with: "It already smells like Christmas and that is why this year, in homage to the combative people, I am going to decree Christmas for October 1st."

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ntn24.com/noticias-politica/entre-decreto-adelantado-de-navidades-y-amenazas-maduro-reacciono-a-un-dia-dificil-511269|work=NTN24|access-date=3 September 2024|date=3 September 2024|language=es|title=Entre decreto adelantado de navidades y amenazas, Maduro reaccionó a un día difícil|trans-title=Between an early Christmas decree and threats, Maduro reacted to a difficult day}}</ref>

<ref name=GuardianChristmas>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/sep/03/venezuela-nicolas-maduro-christmas|work=The Guardian|date=3 September 2024|access-date=4 September 2024|title=Maduro declares Christmas in October amid Venezuela's post-election strife|author=Phillips, Tom}}</ref>

sentences.text: The governments of Argentina, Chile, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Guatemala, Paraguay, Perú, and Uruguay strongly condemned the arrest warrant. Chile called for respect for fundamental freedoms and human rights, condemning repression aimed at political opponents,<ref name=EightCondemn/> joining the other seven countries that rejected the warrant as "another attempt to silence Mr. González, to ignore the will of the Venezuelan people, and constitutes political persecution", characterizing the action as a "dictatorial practice" in a country with no "separation of powers or minimum judicial guarantees and where arbitrary arrests abound".<ref name=EightCondemn/>

references.text: <ref name=EightCondemn>{{cite news|url=https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/09/03/ocho-paises-latinoamericanos-condenaron-la-orden-de-arresto-de-la-justicia-chavista-contra-edmundo-gonzalez-en-venezuela/|work=Infobae|access-date=3 September 2024|date=3 September 2024|language=es|title=Ocho países latinoamericanos condenaron la orden de arresto de la justicia chavista contra Edmundo González en Venezuela|trans-title=Eight Latin American countries condemned the arrest warrant issued by the Chavista justice system against Edmundo González in Venezuela}}</ref>

sentences.text: Brazil's foreign policy advisor, Celso Amorim, stated that there was an "authoritarian escalation" in Venezuela that was "very concerning", and said an actual arrest of González would be a "political arrest". Following a phone conversation between Colombian President Gustavo Petro|Petro and Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva|Lula, their Foreign Ministers released a statement expressing "profound concern about the arrest warrant"; Colombian Senator María Fernanda Cabal criticized Petro for not speaking more forcefully himself, asking if he "feared the dictatorship of Maduro".

references.text: <ref name=BrazilCondemn>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/brazils-amorim-says-arrest-warrant-venezuelas-gonzalez-very-concerning-2024-09-03/|work=Reuters|date=3 September 2024|access-date=3 September 2024|title=Brazil, US condemn arrest warrant for Venezuela opposition leader Gonzalez|author=Paraguassu, Lisandra}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.infobae.com/colombia/2024/09/03/colombia-y-brasil-se-pronunciaron-tras-orden-de-captura-contra-edmundo-gonzalez-hicieron-urgente-llamado-a-la-dictadura-de-maduro/|work=Infobae|access-date=4 September 2024|date=3 September 2024|language=es|title=Colombia y Brasil expresaron su 'profunda preocupación' por la orden de detención contra Edmundo González Urrutia|trans-title=Colombia and Brazil expressed 'profound concern' over the arrest warrant against Edmundo González Urrutia|author=Rodríguez, Mario Alejandro}}</ref>

sentences.text: Brian A. Nichols, a United States Assistant Secretary of State, denounced the warrant as "unjustified" writing that Maduro had "ordered the arrest of the democratic leader who overwhelmingly defeated him at the polls". John Kirby (admiral)|John Kirby, White House National Security Communications Advisor, said the warrant was "just another example of Mr. Maduro's efforts to maintain power by force".<ref name=BrazilCondemn/>

references.text: <ref name=USCondemn>{{cite news|url=https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/09/03/estados-unidos-condeno-la-orden-de-detencion-contra-edmundo-gonzalez-urrutia-en-venezuela/|work=Infobae|access-date=3 September 2024|date=3 September 2024|language=es|title=Estados Unidos condenó la orden de detención contra Edmundo González Urrutia en Venezuela|trans-title=The United States condemned the arrest warrant against Edmundo González Urrutia in Venezuela}}</ref>

sentences.text: The European Union's Josep Borrell "categorically rejected[ed] the arrest warrant', writing: "Enough repression and harassment of the opposition and civil society." Italy's Foreign Ministry issued a statement strongly condemning the arrest warrant, and calling again for vote results to be published and political prisoners to be released.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|url=https://en.mercopress.com/2024/09/04/international-community-concerned-about-arrest-warrant-against-gonzalez-urrutia|agency=MercoPress|title=International community concerned about arrest warrant against González Urrutia|date=4 September 2024|access-date=4 September 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/italy-summons-venezuelan-diplomat-over-arrest-warrant-opposition-leader-2024-09-03/|work=Reuters|title=Italy summons Venezuelan diplomat over arrest warrant for opposition leader|date=3 September 2024|access-date=4 September 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: The Secretary General of the OAS Luis Almagro called for the International Criminal Court to intervene, stating that the political persecution of González was "one more crime in the permanent and continuous legal logic of systematic violation of human rights in the country". The United Nations Human Rights Office denounced a "climate of fear" and persecution of people expressing "their right to political participation".

references.text: <ref name=OASCondemn>{{cite news|url=https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/09/03/la-oea-condeno-la-orden-de-captura-contra-edmundo-gonzalez-en-venezuela/|work=Infobae|access-date=3 September 2024|date=3 September 2024|language=es|title=La OEA condenó la orden de captura contra Edmundo González en Venezuela|trans-title=The OAS condemned the arrest warrant against Edmundo González in Venezuela}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/09/03/la-onu-repudio-el-clima-de-miedo-que-se-vive-en-venezuela-tras-la-orden-de-arresto-contra-edmundo-gonzalez/|work=Infobae|access-date=4 September 2024|date=3 September 2024|language=es|title=La ONU repudió el clima de miedo que se vive en Venezuela tras la orden de arresto contra Edmundo González|trans-title=The UN condemned the climate of fear that exists in Venezuela after the arrest warrant against Edmundo González}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2024/09/1153841|publisher= United Nations|title=Venezuela: UN rights office describes pervasive 'climate of fear'|date=3 September 204|access-date=4 September 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: <!-- The three left-->Brazil, Colombia and Mexico released a joint statement on 8 August that distanced themselves from the TSJ audit, writing that "CNE has the legal mandate to transparently publish electoral results", while calling again for the release of the vote tallies. Following the 22 August TSJ ruling, Mexican president Andrés Manuel López Obrador|Lopez Obrador said he would comment on who had won the election after vote tallies were published. Brazilian president Lula da Silva|Lula and Colombian president Gustavo Petro|Petro, Maduro allies, had no immediate response on the TSJ ruling,

references.text: <ref name=EP-Aug8-BR-CO-MX>{{cite news |author1=Georgina Zerega |author2=Santiago Torrado |title=Brasil, Colombia y México insisten en que el CNE de Venezuela presente las actas y que haya 'una verificación imparcial de los resultados' |trans-title= Brazil, Colombia and Mexico insist that the Venezuelan CNE present vote tallies and that there is an 'impartial verification of results'|url=https://elpais.com/america-colombia/2024-08-08/brasil-colombia-y-mexico-insisten-en-que-el-cne-de-venezuela-presente-las-actas-y-que-haya-una-verificacion-imparcial-de-los-resultados.html |access-date=9 August 2024 |work=El País América Colombia |date=9 August 2024 |language=es-CO}}</ref>

<ref name=ReutersMexicoWait>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/mexico-will-wait-venezuelan-vote-tallies-before-taking-stance-disputed-election-2024-08-23/|title=Mexico will wait for Venezuelan vote tallies before taking stance on disputed election|work=Reuters|date=23 August 2024|access-date=23 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name=HandPicked/><ref name=GuardianPressureGrows/><ref name=InfobaeRegionalCondemnation/> but on 24 August warned Venezuelans to "avoid resorting to acts of violence and repression" and called again for vote tallies to be published.<ref name=APBrazilColombiaCall>{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/brazil-colombia-venezuela-elections-maduro-vote-tallies-b01349aaa4e7ca120dbb84aabebb51d9|title=Brazil and Colombia call on Venezuela to release vote tallies, denounce 'violence and repression'|publisher=Associated Press|date=24 August 2024|access-date=25 August 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: <!--Presidents and former presidents, Latin America-->Chile's left-wing president Gabriel Boric did not recognize the TSJ ruling, and accused the court of "consolidating the fraud", Guatemala's president Bernardo Arévalo, characterized as center-left by ''The Guardian'', joined Boric in the criticism from the left, calling the results a fraud Former Colombian presidents rejected the TSJ ruling: Juan Manuel Santos called it a "hoax" and Iván Duque called it a "blow" to the "millions of citizens who yearn for change and to the brave electoral witnesses who demonstrated through the minutes that Edmundo González won by 30 points".<ref name=InfobaeRegionalCondemnation/> Guillermo Lasso, former president of Ecuador, said he was not surprised by the TSJ ruling, that was "lacking impartiality, independence and credibility" intending to "consolidate the electoral fraud".<ref name=InfobaeRegionalCondemnation/>

references.text: <ref name=GuardianPressureGrows/> in an election stolen<ref name=GuardianUSandLA/> by a "dictatorship that ... represses those who think differently and is indifferent to the largest exile in the world".<ref name=InfobaeRegionalCondemnation>{{cite news|url=https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/08/23/repudio-regional-al-fallo-del-tribunal-supremo-de-venezuela-que-ratifico-el-fraude-y-declaro-ganador-a-nicolas-maduro/ |work=Infobae|language=es|access-date=25 August 2024|date=22 August 2024|title=Repudio regional al fallo del Tribunal Supremo de Venezuela que ratificó el fraude y declaró ganador a Nicolás Maduro|trans-title=Regional condemnation of the ruling of the Supreme Court of Venezuela that ratified the fraud and declared Nicolás Maduro the winner}}</ref>

<ref name=GuardianUSandLA/> in an "indisputable" Venezuelan crisis.<ref name=InfobaeRegionalCondemnation/> Luis Lacalle Pou, president of Uruguay, called the decision a confirmation of fraud from "a dictatorship that closes all doors to an institutional and democratic life for its people".<ref name= GuardianPressureGrows/> Santiago Peña, Paraguayan president, called the TSJ decision "unacceptable" by ratifying "results that do not reflect the will of the Venezuelan people".<ref name=InfobaeRegionalCondemnation/> Jorge Quiroga, former Bolivian president, stated: "Democracy is being buried in Venezuela" in a "blow against popular sovereignty".<ref name=NTN24Quiroga>{{cite news|url=https://www.ntn24.com/noticias-politica/lo-que-sucede-en-venezuela-es-un-golpe-contra-la-soberania-popular-jorge-tuto-quiroga-expresidente-de-bolivia-509340|work=NTN24|language=es|access-date=25 August 2024|date=22 August 2024|title='Lo que sucede en Venezuela es un golpe contra la soberanía popular': Jorge Tuto Quiroga, expresidente de Bolivia|trans-title='What is happening in Venezuela is a coup against popular sovereignty': Jorge Tuto Quiroga, former president of Bolivia}}</ref>

sentences.text: Bolivian president Luis Arce and former president Evo Morales supported the TSJ decision and congratulated Maduro: Arce criticized interference with "democratic institutions of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela" and Morales emphasized the "clear, definitive and unappealable" TSJ ruling.

references.text: <ref name=InfobaeBolivia>{{cite news|url=https://www.infobae.com/america/america-latina/2024/08/25/el-gobierno-de-bolivia-felicito-al-dictador-nicolas-maduro-y-respaldo-la-ratificacion-del-tsj-al-fraude-electoral-en-venezuela/|work=Infobae|access-date=26 August 2024|language=es|date=25 August 2024|title=El gobierno de Bolivia felicitó al dictador Nicolás Maduro y respaldó la ratificación del TSJ al fraude electoral en Venezuela|trans-title=The Bolivian government congratulated dictator Nicolás Maduro and supported the Supreme Court's ratification of electoral fraud in Venezuela}}</ref>

sentences.text: <!--Joint -->Other Latin American leaders rejected the TSJ ruling, along with the US; in a joint statement, Argentina, Costa Rica, Chile, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Guatemala, Panama, Paraguay, and Peru joined the US in calling for an independent vote audit.

references.text: <ref name=GuardianUSandLA>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/aug/23/latin-american-states-and-us-reject-maduro-vote-certification-election-venezuela-supreme-court|work= The Guardian|title=US and 10 Latin American states reject Nicolás Maduro's vote certification|author=Phillips, Tom|date=23 August 2024|access-date=23 August 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: <!--International organizations-->The European Union High Representative for Foreign Affairs Josep Borrell reiterated that the EU would not recognize Maduro without electoral records. The Council of the European Union issued a 25 August statement of concern that evidence was lacking from the CNE—"the body legally and constitutionally responsible for the transparent and detailed publication of the official electoral results"—reiterating the previous UN position. The Council statement called for those responsible for human rights violations to be investigated and prosecuted.<ref name=ElDiarioConsejo/>

references.text: <ref name=APPublicEvidence>{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/brazil-colombia-venezuela-elections-maduro-vote-tallies-b01349aaa4e7ca120dbb84aabebb51d9|publisher=Associated Press|date=24 August 2024|access-date=26 August 2024|title=EU: Maduro has not shown 'necessary public evidence' to declare victory in Venezuela elections|author=Janetsky, Megan}}</ref>

<ref name=ElDiarioReactionsRuling>{{cite news|url=https://eldiario.com/2024/08/23/reacciones-internacionales-sentencia-tsj-convalido-cne/|work=El Diario de Caracas|date=23 August 2024|access-date=25 August 2024|title=Las reacciones tras la sentencia de la Sala Electoral del TSJ que certificó resultados anunciados por el CNE|language=es|trans-title=Reactions following the ruling by the Electoral Chamber of the TSJ that certified the results announced by the CNE}}</ref>

<ref name=ElDiarioConsejo>{{cite news|url=https://eldiario.com/2024/08/24/consejo-de-la-union-europea-preocupacion-agudizacion-poselectoral-en-venezuela/|work=El Diario de Caracas|date=24 August 2024|access-date=25 August 2024|title=Consejo de la Unión Europea manifestó su preocupación por la agudización de la crisis poselectoral en Venezuela|language=es|trans-title=The Council of the European Union expressed its concern about the worsening of the post-electoral crisis in Venezuela|author=Leon, Daniela}}</ref>

sentences.text: United Nations Secretary General António Guterres noted that the TSJ ruling is contested. members of the mission noted the involvement of both Justice Caryslia Rodríguez

references.text: <ref name=ElDiarioReactionsRuling/> Before the TSJ ruling, the UN Fact Finding Mission on Venezuela had stated that both the TSJ and the CNE were "lack[ing] impartiality and independence" and had participated in the "repressive machinery of the State";<ref name=ElDiarioFactFinding>{{cite news|url=https://eldiario.com/2024/08/22/mision-de-determinacion-de-hechos-falta-de-independencia-del-tsj-y-el-cne/|work=El Diario de Caracas|date=22 August 2024|access-date=25 August 2024|title=La Misión de Determinación de Hechos alertó sobre la falta de independencia del TSJ y el CNE|language=es|trans-title=The Fact Finding Mission warned about the lack of independence of the TSJ and the CNE}}</ref>

<ref name=ElDiarioReactionsRuling/> and the CNE president Amoroso with the ruling party, PSUV.<ref name=ElDiarioFactFinding/><ref name=InfobaeUNCondemned>{{cite news|url=https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/08/22/la-onu-condeno-la-falta-de-independencia-e-imparcialidad-del-tribunal-supremo-de-justicia-de-venezuela/|work=Infobae|language=es|access-date=25 August 2024|date=22 August 2024|title=La ONU condenó 'la falta de independencia e imparcialidad' del Tribunal Supremo de Justicia de Venezuela|trans-title=The UN condemned the 'lack of independence and impartiality' of the Supreme Court of Justice of Venezuela}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{See also|2024 Venezuelan presidential election#Censorship}}
A few hours after publication of Machado's 1 August letter in ''The Wall Street Journal'', according to {{ill|VE Sin Filtro|es}}, that newspaper was blocked by some providers in Venezuela.

references.text: <ref name= VOAonWSJ>{{cite news |url= https://www.vozdeamerica.com/a/the-wall-street-journal-se-suma-a-la-lista-de-sitios-web-bloqueados-en-venezuela-y-se-registran-detenciones-de-trabajadores-de-la-prensa/7727406.html |work= Voice of America |title= The Wall Street Journal se suma a los sitios web bloqueados en Venezuela, donde se registran detenciones de comunicadores|language=es |trans-title= The Wall Street Journal joins the list of websites blocked in Venezuela, where journalists have been arrested |date= 2 August 2024 |access-date= 7 August 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 8 August, Maduro ordered that X (social network)|X (formerly Twitter) be blocked for ten days in Venezuela; at 3 pm Venezuelan time, VE Sin Filtro announced the block was effective.

references.text: <ref name="BBC-XBan">{{cite news |title=Venezuela: Nicolás Maduro bans X for 10 days over Elon Musk row |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c5ypx0p84rgo |access-date=9 August 2024 |publisher= BBC News}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/venezuelas-maduro-signs-decree-blocking-x-access-10-days-2024-08-08/ |title= Venezuela's Maduro signs decree blocking X access in country for 10 days |date= 9 August 2024 |access-date= 9 August 2024 |work= Reuters}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |url= https://efectococuyo.com/politica/maduro-anuncia-que-plataforma-x-saldra-10-dia-de-circulacion-en-venezuela/ |work= Efecto Cocuyo |date= 8 August 2024 |access-date= 9 August 2024 |title= Maduro anuncia que plataforma X saldrá 10 días de circulación en Venezuela |language = es |trans-title= Maduro announces that platform X will be out of circulation for 10 days in Venezuela}}</ref>

sentences.text: The legislature passed a new law "to more tightly regulate non-governmental organizations" (NGOs) and their funding.

references.text: <ref name=RegulateNGO>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/venezuela-legislators-approve-law-regulate-ngos-2024-08-15/ |title= Venezuela legislators approve law to regulate NGOs|work=Reuters|date=15 August 2024|access-date=20 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name=AFPParliament>{{cite news|url=https://www.barrons.com/news/venezuelan-parliament-delays-debate-on-fascism-law-f6b6bbc3|work=Barron's|access-date=27 August 2024|title= Venezuelan Parliament Delays Debate On 'Fascism' Law|publisher=Agence France-Presse|date=20 August 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Known as the ''Law on the supervision, regulation, action and financing of non-governmental and related organizations'' (Spanish: ''Ley de fiscalización, regularización, actuación y financiamiento de las organizaciones no gubernamentales y afines'') it was passed in the context of the post-election climate of arbitrary arrests. The law was first proposed in 2023 by Diosdado Cabello; it distinguishes foreign from Venezuelan donors but does not explain the consequences to NGOs that receive donations from foreign sources.<ref name=RegulateNGO/> The Maduro administration has held the position that NGOs are a "facade for the financing of terrorist actions".<ref name=AFPParliament/>

references.text: <ref name=BBCNGOLaw>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/mundo/articles/cjw3v4217npo|publisher=BBC News|title=Venezuela aprueba una ley contra las ONG en medio de las denuncias por arrestos arbitrarios|language=es|trans-title=Venezuela passes anti-NGO law amid allegations of arbitrary arrests|date=15 August 2024|access-date=27 August 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Concerns about another Venezuelan refugee crisis emerged since the election; millions of people who had expected the election to lead to a peaceful transition of power were likely to flee to countries that had already received large numbers of Venezuelan immigrants. Such a large migration was expected to exacerbate the Mexico–United States border crisis|border crisis in the US and to significantly affect other countries in Latin America.<ref name= HundredThousand/><ref name=FalloutSurges/>

references.text: <ref name=FalloutSurges>{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/venezuela-elections-migration-maduro-poverty-chile-colombia-darien-4f922c50fae4bd0c1ca97e0735194c2f|title=As fallout surges from Venezuela's election crisis, the region fears another mass exodus|publisher=Associated Press|first1=Franklin|last1=Briceño|first2=Astrid|last2=Suárez|first3=Nayara|last3=Batschke|date=14 August 2024|access-date=21 August 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: The Venezuelan SNTP ({{ill|Syndicate of National Press Workers|es|Sindicato Nacional de Trabajadores de la Prensa}}) reported that complaints had been filed from dozens of employees who said that they had been fired for like button|liking Machado's WhatsApp posts. ''Le Monde'' wrote that Carmela Longo, a journalist at the "pro-government" newspaper ''Últimas Noticias'' said she was fired shortly before she was arrested; she was charged with terrorism, and released on 26 August.

references.text: <ref name=WSJIntensifiesRepression>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/world/americas/venezuelas-maduro-intensifies-repression-b673f33d|work=The Wall Street Journal|title=Venezuela's Maduro Intensifies Repression|author=Vyas, Kejal|date=23 August 2024|access-date=24 August 2024|id={{ProQuest|3096345456}} }}</ref>

<ref name=LeMondeFiredJournalist>{{cite news|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/08/26/fired-venezuelan-journalist-and-her-son-arrested-by-police-press-union_6721585_4.html|work=Le Monde|access-date=26 August 2024|title=Fired Venezuelan journalist and her son arrested by police: press union|date=26 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name=ReutersJournalistReleased>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/venezuelan-journalist-released-after-being-charged-with-terrorism-union-says-2024-08-26/|work=Reuters|date=26 August 2024|access-date=26 August 2024|title=Venezuelan journalist released after being charged with terrorism, union says}}</ref>

sentences.text: Union representatives and others told Reuters that after employees had been forced to attend pro-Maduro rallies, there were more than 100 forced resignations because of political views at PDVSA among those holding administrative positions, and more in the oil ministry and among workers in the production sector.

references.text: <ref name=ReutersDozens>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/dozens-forced-quit-venezuelas-pdvsa-over-political-views-workers-say-2024-08-21/|work=Reuters|access-date=26 August 2024|title=Dozens forced to quit Venezuela's PDVSA over political views, workers say|author1=Guanipa, Mircely|author2=Buitrago, Deisy|author3=Parraga, Marianna|date=21 August 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Passports of some members of the opposition, activists, journalists, and others were revoked.

references.text: <ref name=BBCRepressionWorsens/><ref name=WSJIntensifiesRepression/><ref name=AidWorkerDisappearance>{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/venezuela-crackdown-maduro-opposition-disputed-election-f59c93361b9b17e83c3af97ce0c7f275|publisher=Associated Press|title=An aid worker's airport disappearance stirs fear of repression following disputed Venezuela election|date=8 August 2024|access-date=24 August 2024|author1=Goodman, Joshua|author2=Garcia Cano, Regina}}</ref>

sentences.text: Andrés Villavicencio, an attorney who served as a poll watcher, told ''The Wall Street Journal'' that masked men came to his home after the election, his passport was voided although its expiry date was 2031, and fearing arrest, he crossed into Colombia without documents and went into exile in Spain.

references.text: <ref name=WSJIntensifiesRepression/><ref name=BBCVillavicencio>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/mundo/articles/cn49wqx4g20o | title=Elecciones en Venezuela: "Tuve que irme del país tras recibir intimidaciones por ser testigo electoral de la oposición" | date=26 August 2024 }}</ref>

sentences.text: Bloomberg reported that Maduro's costly campaign spending on advertising and events caused the Central Bank of Venezuela to sell stockpiled US dollars, leading the parallel market for the Venezuelan bolívar to trade weaker than the official market and threatening to reignite an inflationary cycle.  Bloomberg stated: "In the run-up to the vote, Maduro covered the capital in ads, billboards and murals, and staged almost daily campaign events across the country that often included musical acts and elaborate production", such that the demand for US dollars was greater than supply, "reviving a parallel market used to skirt supply shortages and controls".<ref name=BlowsThrough/>

references.text: <ref name=BlowsThrough>{{cite news|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/maduro-blows-venezuela-dollar-stockpile-120000526.html|publisher=Bloomberg|work=Yahoo News|title=Maduro Blows Through Venezuela's Dollar Stockpile in New Threat to Regime|date= 10 September 2024|access-date=10 September 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Describing the fear since Operation Tun Tun was initiated after the election, a 26 August article in ''The Guardian'' stated: "Many experts believe that ... Maduro will manage to ride out the latest threat to his 11-year rule" and "some compare [the rights violations] to those committed under the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet".

references.text: <ref name=MaduroIntent>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/aug/26/nicolas-maduro-intent-third-term-1600-opponents-venezuela|work=The Guardian|access-date=27 August 2024|title=Maduro intent on third term as 1,600 perceived opponents languish in cells|date=26 August 2024|author1=Phillips, Tom|author2=Rangel, Clavel}}</ref>

sentences.text: To stop opposition within the military and his own government, Maduro divided his security personnel into fragmented units. This tactic, known as "coup proofing", makes consolidating power within ranks more challenging.  Nicas agreed that security forces are a determining factor in whether Maduro steps down, as does Tim Padgett, a journalist covering Latin America for more than 30 years, who states that "allies like Cuba and Russia are lending their ruthless intelligence services to help Maduro detect any signs of betrayal" in the armed forces.

references.text: <ref name=NYTReignEnd/> In addition to the branches of the armed forces, which may spy on each other, the Colectivo (Venezuela)|colectivos—armed groups of civilians supported by the Maduro administration—and several different intelligence services help maintain Maduro's power.<ref name=NYTReignEnd/> Jack Nicas, writes for ''The New York Times'' that the government has also "purchased loyalty by giving senior military officers high-paying jobs or control of state industries".<ref name=NYTReignEnd/><ref name=PadgettStoleElection/> Harold Trinkunas, who specializes in Venezuelan politics and military at Stanford University, told ''The Guardian'' it was likely Maduro would maintain power because of his "grip over the armed forces"<ref name=MaduroIntent/>—a position echoed by Antonio Maria Delgado writing in the ''Miami Herald'' that Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino "holds the Venezuelan regime together" with assistance from Cuba.<ref name=RegimeTogether>{{cite news|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/venezuela/article290766019.html|title=This man holds the Venezuelan regime together. Here's why Maduro doesn't trust him|first=Antonio Maria|last=Delgado|work=Miami Herald|date=5 August 2024|access-date=18 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name=NYTReignEnd>{{cite web|last=Nicas|first=Jack|title=How Could Maduro's Reign in Venezuela End?| work=The New York Times|date=4 August 2024| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/04/world/americas/maduro-regime-venezuela.html|access-date=18 August 2024|archive-url=https://archive.today/20240804091634/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/04/world/americas/maduro-regime-venezuela.html | archive-date=4 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name=PadgettStoleElection>{{cite web|last=Padgett|first=Tim|title=Maduro stole Venezuela's election. Can only the military get it back?|publisher=WLRN Public Radio and Television|date=7 Aug 2024|url=https://www.wlrn.org/americas/2024-08-07/maduro-stole-venezuela-election-military|access-date=18 Aug 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Joshua Goodman wrote for the Associated Press that "so long as Maduro has the support of the armed forces and powerful allies like Russia and China", it is "unrealistic" to think other countries can play a significant role. Laureano Perez Izquierdo wrote in ''Infobae'' on 25 August that the support of Russia's Vladimir Putin, similar to his support of the Al-Assad family in Syria, helps maintain Maduro in power, stating: "Like Al-Assad, Maduro has the unwavering support of Russia and China", along with "Cuba, which penetrated all the structures of [Venezuelan] government and defense". Perez Izquierdo concludes that votes for González will not alter Putin's stance.<ref name=InfobaeMirror/><ref name=WhiteHouseWalksBack/>

references.text: <ref name=APLosesSteam>{{cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/latin-american-effort-mediate-venezuela-standoff-loses-steam-113027403|work=ABC News|publisher= Associated Press|title=Latin American effort to mediate Venezuela standoff loses steam as Maduro consolidates rule|author=Goodman, Joshua|date= 21 August 2024|access-date=27 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name=InfobaeMirror>{{cite news|url= https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/08/25/el-espejo-en-el-que-se-mira-maduro/|language=es|date=25 August 2024|access-date=27 August 2024|title=El espejo en el que se mira Maduro|trans-title=The mirror in which Maduro looks at himself|author=Perez Izquierdo, Laureano }}</ref>

sentences.text: Speculation that Maduro may seek exile in Cuba or Turkey has advanced, but there has been no indication Maduro intends to step down.

references.text: <ref name=MaduroIntent/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.caracaschronicles.com/2024/08/23/turkey-could-play-a-key-role-in-finding-a-resolution-to-venezuelas-crisis/|title=Turkey Could Play a Key Role in Finding a Resolution to Venezuela's Crisis|author=Oner, Imdat |date= 23 August 2024|access-date=27 August 2024|publisher= Caracas Chronicles}}</ref>

<ref name=MaduroIntent/><ref name=InfobaeUSConsiders/> In the context of exit negotiations, Nora Gamez Torres writing for the ''Miami Herald'' also notes that, with the support of Russia, China and Cuba, Maduro "remains defiant".<ref name=WhiteHouseWalksBack>{{cite news|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/venezuela/article291095595.html|title= White House walks back Biden's comments on new elections in Venezuela|work=Miami Herald|last=Gámez Torres|first=Nora|date=15 August 2023|access-date=18 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: Writing for ''Foreign Policy'', Geoff Ramsey and Jason Marczak stated that Maduro "looks weaker than at any point" recently, adding that his repressive moves "do not appear to be the actions of a strongman who feels safe and secure in his position".

references.text: <ref name=WhatsNext/> Speaking the day before the 2024 Venezuelan protests#28 August: One-month election anniversary|rally scheduled for the one-month anniversary of the election, Machado told Reuters that the opposition had a strategy, and indicated that with peaceful protest, international pressure, and "coordination between internal and external forces", Maduro's removal from power was possible notwithstanding support from a "very reduced group of high-ranking soldiers" and the "control of magistrates".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/venezuelas-machado-says-peaceful-protests-external-pressure-could-still-oust-2024-08-27/|work=Reuters|date=27 August 2024|access-date=27 August 2024|author=Sequera, Vivian|title= Venezuela's Machado says peaceful protests, external pressure could still oust Maduro}}</ref>

sentences.text:
in 2019]]
Roman Lejtman wrote in ''Infobae'' on 18 August that, while the US had been negotiating with National Assembly President Jorge Rodríguez (Venezuelan politician)|Jorge Rodríguez, Maduro may have replaced him with Padrino and Diosdado Cabello.

references.text: <ref name=InfobaeUSConsiders>{{cite news |url=https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/08/18/eeuu-analiza-sanciones-contra-la-dictadura-si-maduro-no-cede-la-presidencia-de-venezuela-y-continua-con-la-represion-ilegal/ |work=Infobae|date= 18 August 2024 |access-date=18 August 2024 |title=EEUU analiza sanciones contra la dictadura si Maduro no cede la presidencia de Venezuela y continúa con la represión ilegal|language=es|trans-title=US considers sanctions against the dictatorship if Maduro does not give up the presidency of Venezuela and continues with illegal repression|author=Lejtman, Roman}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 27 August, Maduro announced he would make cabinet changes, saying "we are putting together a new team which will help us transition everything for this era, open new paths ..."

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/venezuelas-maduro-says-he-will-change-half-his-cabinet-2024-08-27/|work=Reuters|date=27 August 2024|access-date=27 August 2024|title=Venezuela's Maduro says he will change half of his cabinet}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/8/27/venezuelas-maduro-reshuffles-cabinet-after-contested-election-victory|title=Venezuela's Maduro reshuffles cabinet after contested election victory|work=Al jazeera|date=27 August 2024|access-date=1 September 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Maduro named Cabello the new Minister of Popular Power of the Interior, Justice and Peace, among other changes. In relation to the events of the 2024 election, this puts Cabello in position to pursue the "consequent persecution of all types of dissidence in Venezuela", according to ''Infobae'', and put him in charge of Identification, Migration and Immigration along with all security forces and law enforcement.

references.text: <ref name=CabelloPower>{{cite news|url=https://www.infobae.com/venezuela/2024/08/27/tras-consolidar-el-fraude-nicolas-maduro-anuncio-un-cambio-en-el-gabinete-de-ministros/|work=Infobae|date=27 August 2024|access-date=27 August 2024|title=Maduro le da más poder a Diosdado Cabello: lo designó Ministro del Interior y Justicia del régimen venezolano|trans-title=Maduro gives Diosdado Cabello more power: he appointed him Minister of the Interior and Justice of the Venezuelan regime}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ntn24.com/noticias-actualidad/maduro-nombra-a-cabello-como-ministro-de-interior-el-organo-que-controla-todas-las-fuerzas-de-orden-y-seguridad-de-venezuela-510029|work=NTN24|language=es|date=27 August 2024|access-date=27 August 2024|title=Maduro nombra a Cabello como ministro de Interior, el órgano que controla todas las fuerzas de orden y seguridad de Venezuela|trans-title=Maduro appoints Cabello as Minister of the Interior, the body that controls all law enforcement and security forces in Venezuela|author=Méndez, Maryorin}}</ref>

sentences.text: Vladimir Padrino remained in the Defense Ministry, while Delcy Rodriguez, Vice President, also assumed the Petroleum Ministry.

references.text: <ref name=MaduroRadicalizes>{{cite news|url=https://www.ntn24.com/noticias-politica/maduro-radicaliza-su-gabinete-ministerial-y-ratifica-a-delcy-rodriguez-y-a-padrino-lopez-510041|work=NTN24|language=es|date=27 August 2024|access-date=27 August 2024|title=Maduro radicaliza su gabinete ministerial y ratifica a Delcy Rodríguez y a Padrino López|trans-title=Maduro radicalizes his ministerial cabinet and confirms Delcy Rodríguez and Padrino López|author=Méndez, Maryorin}}</ref>

sentences.text: González had expressed willingness to negotiate a transfer of power with Maduro, which included not persecuting his party and giving it a place in the National Assembly.

references.text: <ref name="wp27jul">{{cite news | last1=Schmidt | first1=Samantha | last2=Herrero | first2=Ana Vanessa | title=If Maduro loses, will he cede power? Venezuela's election, explained. | newspaper=The Washington Post | date=27 July 2024 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/07/27/venezuela-election-maduro-gonzalez-machado/ | access-date=27 July 2024 | archive-date=27 July 2024 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240727205217/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/07/27/venezuela-election-maduro-gonzalez-machado/ | url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text:
Machado said the opposition was willing to negotiate for Maduro to recognize González's win, according to Nora Gámez Torres writing in the ''Miami Herald'' on 8 August. Machado presented four negotiating points:
# Recognize the 28 July results, in  
# an "orderly and stable democratic transition" with
# "guarantees, safeguards, and incentives" for a rapid outcome that
# "has to be a negotiation in which the people of Venezuela, the leaders that the people of Venezuela trust and the sectors of civil society are represented".<ref name=OfferIncentives/>

references.text: <ref name=OfferIncentives>{{cite news |title= Machado: Opposition would offer Maduro incentives to negotiate transition to democracy |date= 8 August 2024 |first = Nora |last= Gámez Torres |work= Miami Herald |url= https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/venezuela/article290893994.html |access-date= 9 August 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Brazilian president Lula da Silva|Lula and Colombian president Gustavo Petro|Petro, leftist allies of Maduro who had been pressing him to release the vote tallies, proposed instead on 15 August that the election should be repeated—Venezuelan law provides for that possibility if an election is annulled. At the same time, Lula made his strongest criticism of Maduro since the election, stating that the Venezuela administration has an "authoritarian slant" and is "a very unpleasant regime", while again calling for Maduro to release the vote tallies.<ref name= LulaCriticizes/>

references.text: <ref name= CriesFoul>{{cite news |title= Brazil, Colombia urge new Venezuela vote, as opposition cries foul |first1= Javier |last1= Tovar |first2= Barbara |last2= Agelvis|date= 15 August 2024 |work= Agence France-Presse |publisher= Yahoo News |url= https://sg.news.yahoo.com/brazils-president-suggests-vote-venezuela-155910749.html |access-date= 16 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name= FacesSetback>{{cite news |url= https://apnews.com/article/brazil-lula-venezuela-election-maduro-1c3afbf01f4c85e7903c2fc3d7fdbf38 |publisher= Associated Press |title= Venezuela's opposition faces setback after countries suggest repeat of presidential election |first1= Gabriela |last1= Sa Pessoa |first2= Regina |last2= Garcia Cano |date= 15 August 2024 |access-date= 16 August 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: The opposition and the Maduro government each rejected the idea—both stating they had already won.

references.text: <ref name=AmidCalls>{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/08/15/venezuela-election-maduro-gonzalez-maduro/ |newspaper= The Washington Post |title= Amid calls for new elections in Venezuela, opposition weighs next move |first1= Samantha |last1= Schmidt |first2= Marina |last2= Dias |date= 15 August 2024 |access-date= 16 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name= RejectCalls>{{cite news |url= https://www.nysun.com/article/maduro-machado-reject-calls-from-lula-petro-biden-for-a-second-venezuelan-election |title= Maduro, Machado Reject Calls From Lula, Petro, Biden for a Second Venezuelan Election |work= The New York Sun |first= Rafael |last= Oliveira |date= 16 August 2024 |access-date= 17 August 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Mexican President López stated on 15 August that he did not consider the proposal by Brazil and Colombia to be "prudent", that he had not spoken with the presidents of those countries since 1 August, and that he had no plans to continue dialogue with them until the TSJ issues a ruling; he did not endorse Maduro as the winner of the election, but criticized those countries and organizations that have declared that González won, adding that Mexico is "not in favor of one or the other".

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |url= https://efe.com/mundo/2024-08-15/venezuela-lopez-obrador-nuevas-elecciones-lula-mexico/ |agency= EFE |date= 15 August 2024 |access-date= 17 August 2024 |title= López Obrador no cree 'prudente' pedir nuevas elecciones en Venezuela |language=es |trans-title= López Obrador does not believe it is 'prudent' to call for new elections in Venezuela}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |url= https://english.elpais.com/international/2024-08-16/proposals-from-brazil-and-colombia-for-new-elections-or-a-coalition-in-venezuela-rejected.html |work= El País |date= 16 August 2024 |access-date= 17 August 2024 |title= Proposals from Brazil and Colombia for new elections or a coalition in Venezuela rejected |first= Florantonia |last= Singer}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.ntn24.com/noticias-politica/presidente-de-mexico-anuncio-que-no-hablara-mas-por-ahora-con-los-presidentes-de-colombia-y-brasil-sobre-la-crisis-politica-en-venezuela-507873 |work= NTN24 |date= 14 August 2024 |access-date= 17 August 2024 |title= Presidente de México anunció que no hablará más 'por ahora' con los presidentes de Colombia y Brasil sobre la crisis política en Venezuela |language=es|trans-title= President of Mexico announced that he will no longer speak 'for now' with the presidents of Colombia and Brazil about the political crisis in Venezuela}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{further|U.S. sanctions during the Venezuelan crisis}}
On 19 July 2024, Elliott Abrams, diplomat and former special representative of the Trump administration for Venezuela, suggested that the United States should offer amnesty to Maduro.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|url= https://albertonews.com/internacionales/elliott-abrams-sugiere-a-ee-uu-ofrecerle-una-amnistia-a-maduro-para-que-acepte-su-derrota-el-28j/|title= Elliott Abrams sugiere a EE.UU. ofrecerle una amnistía a Maduro para que acepte su derrota el 28J|date= 19 July 2024|language= es|trans-title= Elliott Abrams suggests that the US offer Maduro amnesty so that he accepts his defeat on June 28|access-date= 29 July 2024|work= Alberto News|archive-date= 29 July 2024|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20240729040337/https://albertonews.com/internacionales/elliott-abrams-sugiere-a-ee-uu-ofrecerle-una-amnistia-a-maduro-para-que-acepte-su-derrota-el-28j/|url-status= live}}</ref>

<ref name="o850">{{cite web | last=Abrams | first=Elliott | title=Can Maduro Be Negotiated Out of Venezuela? | website=Council on Foreign Relations | date=19 July 2024 | url=https://www.cfr.org/blog/can-maduro-be-negotiated-out-venezuela | access-date=29 July 2024 | archive-date=25 July 2024 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240725045624/https://www.cfr.org/blog/can-maduro-be-negotiated-out-venezuela | url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The US denied an 11 August report in ''The Wall Street Journal'' that it had offered Maduro amnesty in exchange for him conceding the election; a senior US official told the ''Miami Herald'' that the US "has not offered Nicolás Maduro and his aides any form of amnesty to leave power in Venezuela, but is open to all possibilities", and White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre confirmed the denial.<ref name=NotOffered/>

references.text: <ref name=NotOffered>{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/us-says-it-has-not-offered-maduro-amnesty-since-election-2024-08-12/ |title= US says it has not offered Maduro amnesty since election|work= Reuters |date= 12 August 2024 |access-date= 13 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref name=NoUSAmnesty>{{cite news |url= https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/venezuela/article290959689.html |title= U.S. says it hasn't offered Maduro amnesty to leave power, but is open to suggestions |work= Miami Herald |first1= Michael |last1 = Wilner |first2= Antonio Maria |last2= Delgado |date= 11 August 2024 |access-date= 12 August 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Forero |first1=Juan |last2=Garip |first2=Patricia |last3=Vyas |first3=Kejal |date=11 August 2024 |title=In Secret Talks, U.S. Offers Amnesty to Venezuela's Maduro for Ceding Power |url=https://www.wsj.com/world/americas/in-secret-talks-u-s-offers-amnesty-to-venezuelas-maduro-for-ceding-power-e22b4821?mod=hp_lead_pos2 |url-access=subscription |access-date=12 August 2024 |work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref>

sentences.text: A 10 August article in ''The Washington Post'' stated that the Biden administration was deferring to the lead of the three presidents in Brazil, Colombia and Mexico; unnamed administration sources said there was time for other strategies before the January 2025 inauguration, but the near-term focus was on providing an exit strategy rather than more forceful options like sanctions. Florida Senator Marco Rubio and other critics said this strategy was empowering Maduro and allowing him to continue repression.<ref name=WAPOAmidTumult/>

references.text: <ref name=WAPOAmidTumult>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2024/08/10/us-policy-venezuela/|newspaper=The Washington Post|title=Amid Venezuela tumult, U.S. wants Latin American countries to lead in finding a solution|first1=Karen|last1=DeYoung|first2=Samantha|last2=Schmidt|date=10 August 2024|access-date=18 August 2024|id={{ProQuest|3091217702}} }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 18 August, an unnamed member of the Biden administration stated that negotiations with Maduro were not progressing because Maduro won't accept mention of defeat, and "does not want to negotiate twice" (once now and once after the US presidential elections), according to ''Infobae'' in an article that also stated Maduro intends to "delay the entire political process until after the elections in the United States".

references.text: <ref name=InfobaeUSConsiders/> White House sources told ''Infobae'' that sanctions aimed at individuals in the military and security forces were being studied.<ref name=InfobaeUSConsiders/> Ramsey and Maczak wrote on 27 August that the Biden Administration was "keeping its cards close", seeking to avoid seeing Maduro draw closer to Russia and China; they wrote that after having provided exemptions from existing sanctions that allowed oil to keep flowing from Venezuela, the US was taking it slow on imposing more sanctions.<ref name=WhatsNext>{{cite news|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2024/08/27/venezuela-election-maduro-gonzalez-machado-us-sanctions-diplomacy/|work=Foreign Policy|title=What's Next for U.S. Policy in Venezuela?|author1=Ramsey, Geoff|author2=Marczak, Jason |date=27 August 2024|access-date=27 August 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 12 September, the United States Department of the Treasury sanctioned 16 individuals who are linked to the election fraud. Among the individuals who are sanctioned by the Department of the Treasury are senior figures in the TSJ, CNE, and the military including the prominent names such as Caryslia Rodríguez, Domingo Antonio Hernández Larez, and others.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cjw3wn6geewo |title=US sanctions Maduro allies linked to Venezuela's disputed election |last=Buschschlüter |first=Vanessa |date=12 September 2024 |website=bbc.com |publisher=BBC |access-date=13 September 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Venezuelan economist and former advisor to the National Assembly Francisco Rodríguez (economist)|Francisco Rodríguez argued in favor of a peaceful transition of power to be initiated via a power sharing|power-sharing agreement similar to that of the 1989 Polish Round Table Agreement and Contract Sejm in Poland. he suggested that Maduro would symbolically retain the presidency, Maduro's supporters would retain the security and police ministries, and the opposition would have a prime minister and the rest of the cabinet.

sentences.text: On 15 August, Brazilian president Lula and Colombian president Petro proposed power-sharing. Maduro and the opposition rejected the proposal.
